ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I improved on my writing, reading, and speaking significantly throughout the course. It was truly unbelievable how much my Chinese improved over the last 3 months.

I learned new grammar, vocabulary, sentence structures. I learned how to study daily for a course and develop a schedule. I learned how to deal with not growing as much as I wanted to and keep pushing.

I learned a lot about the Chinese language and culture. In particular, I developed the ability to read and write Chinese characters while also refining my pronunciation. I thought the class was a good amount of work but it was worth it.
Writing and reading new characters.
I developed a greated knowledge of writing and reading Chinese
I learned the fundamentals of basic Mandarin as well as learning over 300 characters. I also learned the rules of grammar in Mandarin.
A whole lot of Chinese!

Because of this course I was able to reconnect with the culture and knowledge I became disconnected from when I moved back home from China, and for that I am so very thankful. I learned and practiced every essential skill and language speaker can have. Reading, writing, speaking, fluency, etc.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: I feel like teaching some strategies to memorize the characters would help the course a lot. The speaking and reading homeworks are extremely useful.

It was a very engaging course. I knew what to expect every morning and nothing came as a surprise. I liked the 4+1 structure of the class. This class encourages fast-paced learning and I'm glad because it felt very rewarding at the end.

Strengths: good pace
Weaknesses: Too much course work at times
Strengths are the small class sizes and great interaction with professor. I also really like the 4+1 asynchronous schedule. No apparent weaknesses.

It prepares you well for learning Mandarin and goes above and beyond in teaching the fundamentals. It was also fast-paced, facilitating learning. The workload was a bit high, yet suitable for this course.

Strengths: An absolutely amazing course with a great professor that is well-structured and encourages great engagement

Weaknesses: no major weaknesses
I genuinely think this course is setup perfectly to push you while not overwhelming you.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Definitely, if being a heritage student and interested in Chinese, since it is very rewarding to see your language level improve so fast, but at the same time the fast-paced learning can be intimidating and challenging.

Yes -- only if you have previous Chinese knowledge. It goes by really fast and you'll struggle to catch up if you're really behind at times. It is really rewarding at the end and you'll find yourself loving learning the language.
Yes, I would. It's really satisfying at the end of the semester when you know 400+ Chinese characters under your belt and can apply them in the real world.
Yes if you really want to improve your Chinese.
Yes. Great course with small class size. I feel that I learned a lot without feeling too overwhelmed.
I would recommend this course to another student as it definitely teaches Mandarin well. The structure of the course is also well thought out for learning Mandarin.
Yes. This course allowed me to learn so so much while enjoying it so much.
I would definitely recommend this course to anyone interested in genuinely learning the language, and on a path toward proficiency.
